hints.content:
We know the $\blueD{\text{number of groups}}$:

There are $\blueD{9}$ canoes.

And we know the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$:

Each canoe holds $\purpleC3$ campers.

The product will tell us the $\greenD{\text{total}}$.

In this problem, the $\greenD{\text{total}}$ is the total number of campers that can ride in canoes.
The product tells us the $\greenD{\text{total number of campers that can ride in canoes}}$ .

question.content:
A summer camp has $9$ canoes. Each canoe holds $3$ campers. 

**What does the expression $9\times3$ represent?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: Total number of campers that can ride in canoes
Number of campers in each canoe
